messageBody:
Pat Farrell wrote:

> It may be that JUnit is focused on single unit tests that are executed
> sequentially. I haven't see "Manning's "TDD in Action" '
> so I could be wrong.

JUnit is designed that way, yes: test isolation is very important, and a
central notion of effective object testing. Still, I'm not sure that
matters: if you can write a test that starts the desired threads, does
work, then lets the threads finish (or times out, as needed), then those
tests can execute sequentially, if slowly, while still testing threading
issues.
